user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connection_close_:
```c
static void
new_connection_close_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  mhd_assert (connection->daemon == daemon);
  mhd_assert (! connection->in_cleanup);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->next);
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextX);
#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (NULL == connection->nextE);
#endif /* EPOLL_SUPPORT */

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->tls_session)
  {
    mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
    gnutls_deinit (connection->tls_session);
  }
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_socket_close_chk_ (connection->socket_fd);
  MHD_ip_limit_del (daemon,
                    connection->addr,
                    connection->addr_len);
  if (NULL != connection->addr)
    free (connection->addr);
  free (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct uses of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the shown function. The code only performs assertions, calls to other functions (mhd_assert, gnutls_deinit, MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_ip_limit_del) and frees a pointer. The free is guarded by a NULL check (if (NULL != connection->addr) free(connection->addr);), so there is no immediate risk of out‑of‑bounds access due to a string operation here. The only pointer passed to another routine is connection->addr (with connection->addr_len) — if that other routine uses string.h functions incorrectly, it would need to be inspected within its own implementation, but that is outside the provided code fragment. Likewise, gnutls_deinit and the MHD_* helper functions are external; their internals would need review if suspected, but they are not present in this snippet. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that directly violate or trigger MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
